etymologies: Middle English (denoting the forehead): from Old French front (noun), fronter (verb), from Latin frons, front-‘forehead, front’

definitions: the side or part of an object that presents itself to view or that is normally seen or used first; the most forward part of something

examples.text: a page at the front of the book had been torn out
he sealed the envelope and wrote on the front

definitions: the position directly ahead of someone or something; the most forward position or place

examples.text: she quickly turned her head to face the front

definitions: the forward-facing part of a person's body, on the opposite side to their back

examples.text: she rolled over onto her front

definitions: the part of a garment covering a person's front

examples.text: oatmeal slopped from the tray onto his shirt front

definitions: a woman's bust or cleavage

examples.text: get your eyes off my front, meathead

definitions: any face of a building, especially that of the main entrance

examples.text: the west front of the Cathedral

definitions: the foremost line or part of an armed force; the furthest position that an army has reached and where the enemy is or may be engaged

examples.text: his regiment was immediately sent to the front

definitions: the direction toward which a line of troops faces when formed.
a particular formation of troops for battle

examples.text: the Spartans preserving an even and unbroken front

definitions: a particular situation or sphere of operation

examples.text: there was some good news on the jobs front

definitions: an organized political group

examples.text: the Palestinian Liberation Front

crossReferenceMarkers: See cold front, occluded front, warm front
definitions: the forward edge of an advancing mass of air.
shortDefinitions: forward edge of mass of air

definitions: an appearance or form of behavior assumed by a person to conceal their genuine feelings

examples.text: she put on a brave front

definitions: a person or organization serving as a cover for subversive or illegal activities

examples.text: the CIA identified the company as a front for a terrorist group

definitions: a well-known or prestigious person who acts as a representative, rather than an active member, of an organization.
shortDefinitions: well-known or prestigious person who acts as representative, rather than active member

definitions: boldness and confidence of manner

examples.text: he's got a bit of talent and a lot of front

definitions: a person's face or forehead.
of or at the front

examples.text: the front cover of the magazine
she was in the front yard

definitions: (of a vowel sound) formed by raising the tongue, excluding the blade and tip, toward the hard palate.
shortDefinitions: (of vowel sound) formed by raising tongue

definitions: (of a building or piece of land) have the front facing or directed toward

examples.text: the houses that front Beacon Street
we sold the uphill land that fronted on the road

definitions: be or stand in front of

examples.text: they reached the hedge fronting the garden

shortDefinitions: be or stand in front of

definitions: provide (something) with a front or facing of a particular type or material

examples.text: a metal box fronted by an alloy panel
a glass-fronted bookcase

definitions: lead or be the most prominent member in (an organization, activity, or group of musicians)

examples.text: the group is fronted by two girl singers

definitions: present or host (a television or radio program)

examples.text: she is set to front a new BBC show

definitions: act as a front or cover for someone or something acting illegally or wishing to conceal something

examples.text: he fronted for them in illegal property deals

shortDefinitions: act as cover for illegal activity

definitions: adopt a particular expression or form of behavior to conceal one's genuine feelings

examples.text: I can't front, I never really listened to much of his music

shortDefinitions: assume appearance to conceal one's genuine feelings

definitions: stand face to face with; confront

examples.text: Tom fronted him with unwavering eyes

definitions: articulate (a vowel sound) with the tongue further forward

examples.text: all speakers use raised and fronted variants more in spontaneous speech

definitions: place (a sentence element) at the beginning of a sentence instead of in its usual position, typically for emphasis or as a feature of some dialects, as in horrible it was.
shortDefinitions: place element at beginning of sentence

definitions: used to summon someone to the front or to command them to assume a forward-facing position, as in calling a bellhop to the front desk or giving orders to troops on parade

examples.text: scouts, front and center!

etymologies: Middle English: from a-‘in, on’ + round

notes.text: Are around and round (as preposition and adverbial particle) interchangeable? In US English, the normal form in most contexts is around; round is generally regarded as informal or nonstandard and is standard only in certain fixed expressions, as in the park is open year round and they went round and round in circles

definitions: located or situated on every side

examples.text: the mountains towering all around
a building visible for miles around

definitions: so as to surround someone or something

examples.text: everyone crowded around
a pool with banks all the way around

shortDefinitions: so as to surround person or thing

definitions: so as to give support and companionship

examples.text: sometimes you wonder how many friends will rally around you when your life hits rock-bottom

shortDefinitions: so as to give support and companionship

definitions: with circular motion

examples.text: the boats were spun around by waterspouts

definitions: so as to cover or take in the whole area surrounding a particular center

examples.text: she paused to glance around admiringly at the decor

shortDefinitions: so as to cover or take in whole area surrounding particular center

definitions: so as to reach everyone in a particular group or area

examples.text: he passed a newspaper clipping around

shortDefinitions: so as to reach everyone in particular group or area

definitions: so as to rotate and face in the opposite direction

examples.text: Jack seized her by the shoulders and turned her around
having him in my corner has turned my career around

definitions: so as to lead in another direction

examples.text: it was the last house before the road curved around

shortDefinitions: so as to lead in another direction

definitions: used in describing the position of something, typically with regard to the direction in which it is facing or its relation to other items

examples.text: the picture shows the pieces the wrong way around

shortDefinitions: used in describing position of something

definitions: used to describe a situation in terms of the relation between people, actions, or events

examples.text: it was he who was attacking her, not the other way around

shortDefinitions: used to describe situation in terms of relation between people or events

definitions: in or to many places throughout a locality

examples.text: word got around that he was on the verge of retirement
his only ambition is to drive around in a sports car

definitions: so as to reach a new place or position, typically by moving from one side of something to the other

examples.text: he made his way around to the back of the building
they went the long way around by the main road

shortDefinitions: so as to reach new place or position

definitions: used to convey an ability to navigate or orient oneself

examples.text: I like pupils to find their own way around

shortDefinitions: used to convey ability to navigate or orient oneself

definitions: used to convey the idea of visiting someone else

examples.text: why don't you come around to my office?

shortDefinitions: used to convey idea of visiting someone else

definitions: randomly or unsystematically; here and there

examples.text: one of them was glancing nervously around
John tried to focus on her but she kept moving around

definitions: in existence, in the vicinity, or in active use

examples.text: there was no one around
barley has been around for a long time
by being around I threaten her happiness

definitions: near at hand

examples.text: he would want to have her around as much as possible

definitions: approximately; about

examples.text: software costs would be around $1,500
I returned to my hotel around 3 a.m.

notes.text: Are around and round (as preposition and adverbial particle) interchangeable? In US English, the normal form in most contexts is around; round is generally regarded as informal or nonstandard and is standard only in certain fixed expressions, as in the park is open year round and they went round and round in circles

definitions: on every side of

examples.text: the palazzo is built around a courtyard
the hills around the city

definitions: (of something abstract) having (the thing mentioned) as a focal point

examples.text: our entire culture is built around those loyalties
you can organize your essay around an existing critical controversy

definitions: in or to many places throughout (a community or locality)

examples.text: cycling around the village
a number of large depots around the country

shortDefinitions: in or to many places throughout

definitions: so as to pass (a place or object) in a curved or approximately circular route

examples.text: he walked around the airfield
it can drill around corners

definitions: so as to encircle or embrace (someone or something)

examples.text: he put his arm around her
warming her hands around a cup of coffee
the polar vortex around Antarctica

shortDefinitions: so as to encircle or embrace

etymologies: Middle English: shortening of Old French estrange, from Latin extraneus‘external, strange’

definitions: unusual or surprising in a way that is unsettling or hard to understand

examples.text: children have some strange ideas
he's a very strange man
it is strange how things change

definitions: not previously visited, seen, or encountered; unfamiliar or alien

examples.text: a harsh accent that was strange to his ears
she found herself in bed in a strange place

definitions: unaccustomed to or unfamiliar with

examples.text: I am strange to the work

definitions: (of a subatomic particle) having a nonzero value for strangeness.
shortDefinitions: (of subatomic particle) having non-zero value for strangeness

etymologies: late Middle English: perhaps a back-formation from striped, of Dutch or Low German origin; compare with Middle Dutch and Middle Low German strīpe

definitions: a long narrow band or strip, typically of the same width throughout its length, differing in color or texture from the surface on either side of it

examples.text: a pair of blue shorts with pink stripes

shortDefinitions: long, narrow band or strip differing in colour or texture from surface on either side of it

definitions: a blow with a scourge or lash.
a chevron sewn on to a uniform to denote military rank

examples.text: he was wearing his old uniform without its sergeant's stripes

shortDefinitions: chevron sewn on to uniform to denote military rank

definitions: a type or category

examples.text: entrepreneurs of all stripes are joining in the offensive

definitions: mark with stripes

examples.text: her body was striped with bands of sunlight

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French basket, of unknown ultimate origin

definitions: a container used to hold or carry things, typically made from interwoven strips of cane or wire

examples.text: a laundry basket

definitions: a facility on a website that records items selected by a customer for purchase until the transaction is completed

examples.text: click on the order button to add a title to your basket

shortDefinitions: facility on website that records items selected for purchase

definitions: a structure suspended from a hot-air balloon for carrying the crew, equipment, and ballast.
shortDefinitions: structure suspended from hot-air balloon for carrying crew and ballast

definitions: a group or range of currencies or investments

examples.text: the European currency unit is made up of a basket of ten currencies

definitions: a net fixed on a hoop used as the goal.
a goal scored.

etymologies: Old English stēap ‘extending to a great height’, of West Germanic origin; related to steeple and stoop

definitions: (of a slope, flight of stairs, angle, ascent, etc.) rising or falling sharply; nearly perpendicular

examples.text: she pushed the bike up the steep hill

definitions: (of a rise or fall in an amount) large or rapid

examples.text: the steep rise in unemployment

definitions: (of a price or demand) not reasonable; excessive

examples.text: a steep membership fee

definitions: (of a claim or account) exaggerated or incredible

examples.text: this is a rather steep statement

definitions: a steep mountain slope

examples.text: hair-raising steeps

etymologies: Middle English: of Germanic origin; related to stoup

definitions: soak (food or tea) in water or other liquid so as to extract its flavor or to soften it

examples.text: the chilies are steeped in olive oil
the noodles should be left to steep for 3–4 minutes

shortDefinitions: soak food or tea in water or other liquid so as to extract its flavour or to soften it

definitions: soak or saturate (cloth) in water or other liquid

examples.text: sheets were steeped in mercury sulfate as a disinfectant

shortDefinitions: soak or saturate cloth in water or other liquid

definitions: surround or fill with a quality or influence

examples.text: a city steeped in history

shortDefinitions: surround or fill with quality or influence

etymologies: Old English stān (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch steen and German Stein. The verb dates from Middle English (first recorded in stone (sense 1 of the verb))

definitions: hard solid nonmetallic mineral matter of which rock is made, especially as a building material

examples.text: the houses are built of stone
high stone walls

shortDefinitions: hard solid non-metallic mineral matter of which rock is made

definitions: used in similes and metaphors to refer to weight or lack of feeling, expression, or movement

examples.text: Isabel stood as if turned to stone
the elevator dropped like a stone
her face became as hard as stone

shortDefinitions: used in similes and metaphors to refer to weight or lack of feeling or movement

definitions: a small piece of rock found on the ground.
shortDefinitions: small piece of rock found on ground

definitions: a meteorite made of rock, as opposed to metal.
shortDefinitions: meteorite made of rock, as opposed to metal

definitions: a calculus; a gallstone or kidney stone.
a piece of stone shaped for a purpose, especially one of commemoration, ceremony, or demarcation

examples.text: a memorial stone
boundary stones

shortDefinitions: piece of stone shaped for purpose

definitions: a gem or jewel

examples.text: a gold ring with a small dark red stone

definitions: a round piece or counter, originally made of stone, used in various board games such as backgammon.
shortDefinitions: round piece or counter, originally made of stone, used in various board games

definitions: a large flat table or sheet, originally made of stone and later usually of metal, on which pages of type were made up.
a hard seed in a cherry, plum, peach, and some other fruits.
shortDefinitions: hard seed in cherry, plum, peach

definitions: a unit of weight equal to 14 pounds (6.35 kg)

examples.text: I weighed 10 stone

shortDefinitions: unit of weight equal to 14 lb

definitions: a natural shade of whitish-gray or brownish-gray

examples.text: stone stretch trousers

shortDefinitions: natural shade of whitish or brownish-grey

definitions: throw stones at

examples.text: policemen were stoned by the crowd

definitions: remove the stone from (a fruit)

examples.text: halve, stone, and peel the avocados

definitions: build, face, or pave with stone

examples.text: the honey-stoned, eighteenth-century city

shortDefinitions: build, face, or pave with stone

etymologies: Old English standan (verb), stand (noun), of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin stare and Greek histanai, also by the noun stead

definitions: have or maintain an upright position, supported by one's feet

examples.text: Lionel stood in the doorway
she stood still, heart hammering

notes.text: no object, usually with adverbial of place

shortDefinitions: have or maintain upright position, supported by one's feet

definitions: rise to one's feet

examples.text: the two men stood up and shook hands

definitions: move to and remain in a specified position

examples.text: she stood aside to let them enter

definitions: place or set in an upright or specified position

examples.text: don't stand the plant in direct sunlight

notes.text: with object and adverbial of place

shortDefinitions: place or set in upright or specified position

definitions: (of an object, building, or settlement) be situated in a particular place or position

examples.text: the town stood on a hill
the hotel stands in three acres of gardens

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of place

shortDefinitions: be situated in particular place or position

definitions: (of a building or other vertical structure) remain upright and entire rather than fall into ruin or be destroyed

examples.text: after the heavy storms, only one house was left standing

shortDefinitions: remain upright and entire rather than fall into ruin or be destroyed

definitions: remain valid or unaltered

examples.text: my decision stands
his strikeout record stood for 38 years

definitions: (especially of a vehicle) remain stationary

examples.text: the train now standing on track 3

definitions: (of a liquid) collect and remain motionless

examples.text: avoid planting in soil where water stands in winter

definitions: (of food, a mixture, or liquid) rest without disturbance, typically so as to infuse or marinate

examples.text: pour boiling water over the fruit and leave it to stand for 5 minutes

definitions: (of a ship) remain on a specified course

examples.text: the ship was standing north

definitions: be in a specified state or condition

examples.text: since mother's death the house had stood empty
sorry, darling—I stand corrected

shortDefinitions: be in specified state or condition

definitions: adopt a particular attitude toward a matter or issue

examples.text: students should consider where they stand on this issue

shortDefinitions: adopt particular attitude towards matter or issue

definitions: be of a specified height

examples.text: Sampson was a small man, standing 5 ft. 4 in. tall

definitions: be at (a particular level or value)

examples.text: the budget stood at $14 million per annum

definitions: be in a situation where one is likely to do something

examples.text: investors stood to lose heavily

shortDefinitions: be in situation where one is likely to do something

definitions: act in a specified capacity

examples.text: he stood watch all night

definitions: (of a stallion) be available for breeding.
withstand (an experience or test) without being damaged

examples.text: small boats that could stand the punishment of heavy seas

shortDefinitions: withstand experience or test without being damaged

definitions: be able to endure or tolerate

examples.text: I can't stand the way Mom talks to him

shortDefinitions: be able to endure or tolerate

definitions: be a candidate in an election

examples.text: he stood for parliament in 1968

definitions: provide (food or drink) for someone at one's own expense

examples.text: somebody in the bar would stand him a beer

shortDefinitions: provide food or drink for someone at one's own expense

definitions: an attitude toward a particular issue; a position taken in an argument

examples.text: the party's tough stand on welfare
his traditionalist stand

definitions: a determined effort to resist or fight for something

examples.text: this was not the moment to make a stand for independence
we have to take a stand against racism

shortDefinitions: determined effort to resist or fight for something

definitions: an act of holding one's ground against or halting to resist an opposing force

examples.text: Custer's legendary last stand

shortDefinitions: act of holding one's ground against or halting to resist opposing force

definitions: a rack, base, or piece of furniture for holding, supporting, or displaying something

examples.text: a microphone stand

shortDefinitions: rack, base, or piece of furniture for holding, supporting, or displaying something

definitions: a small stall or booth in a street, market, or public building from which goods are sold

examples.text: a hot-dog stand

shortDefinitions: small stall or booth in street, market, or public building

definitions: a raised platform for a band, orchestra, or speaker.
shortDefinitions: raised platform for band or speaker

definitions: the place where someone typically stands or sits

examples.text: she took her stand in front of the desks

shortDefinitions: place where someone stands or sits

definitions: a place where vehicles, typically taxicabs, wait for passengers

examples.text: a taxi stand
the terminal's facilities include additional aircraft parking stands

shortDefinitions: place where vehicles wait for passengers

definitions: a witness box

examples.text: Sergeant Harris took the stand

definitions: a large raised tiered structure for spectators, typically at a sports arena

examples.text: her parents watched from the stands

shortDefinitions: large raised tiered structure for spectators

definitions: a cessation from motion or progress

examples.text: the train drew to a stand by the signal box

definitions: each halt made on a touring theatrical production to give one or more performances.
shortDefinitions: each halt made on touring theatrical production to give one or more performances

definitions: a group of growing plants of a specified kind, especially trees

examples.text: a stand of poplars

shortDefinitions: group of growing plants of specified kind

etymologies: Middle English (originally in the sense ‘tolerate’): from Old French supporter, from Latin supportare, from sub-‘from below’ + portare‘carry’

definitions: bear all or part of the weight of; hold up

examples.text: the dome was supported by a hundred white columns

shortDefinitions: bear all or part of weight of

definitions: give assistance to, especially financially; enable to function or act

examples.text: the government gives $2.5 billion a year to support the activities of the voluntary sector

definitions: provide with a home and the necessities of life

examples.text: my main concern was to support my family

shortDefinitions: provide with home and necessities of life

definitions: produce enough food and water for; be capable of sustaining

examples.text: the land had lost its capacity to support life

shortDefinitions: produce enough food and water for

definitions: give approval, comfort, or encouragement to

examples.text: the proposal was supported by many delegates
I like to visit her to support her

shortDefinitions: give approval, comfort, or encouragement to

definitions: be actively interested in and concerned for the success of (a particular sports team)

examples.text: fans should always support their team fully, no matter what

shortDefinitions: be actively interested in and concerned for success of

definitions: (of a pop or rock group or performer) function as a secondary act to (another) at a concert.
shortDefinitions: (of pop or rock group or performer) function as secondary act to another at concert

definitions: suggest the truth of; corroborate

examples.text: the studies support our findings

definitions: (of a computer or operating system) allow the use or operation of (a program, language, or device)

examples.text: the new versions do not support the graphical user interface standard

shortDefinitions: (of computer or operating system) allow use or operation of

definitions: endure; tolerate

examples.text: at work during the day I could support the grief

definitions: a thing that bears the weight of something or keeps it upright

examples.text: the best support for a camera is a tripod

shortDefinitions: thing that bears weight of something or keeps it upright

definitions: the action or state of bearing the weight of something or someone or of being so supported

examples.text: she clutched the sideboard for support

shortDefinitions: action of supporting something or someone or state of being supported

definitions: material assistance

examples.text: he urged that military support be sent to protect humanitarian convoys
support staff

definitions: approval, encouragement, or comfort

examples.text: the paper printed many letters in support of the government
she's been through a bad time and needs our support

definitions: a source of comfort or encouragement

examples.text: he was a great support when her father died

definitions: technical help given to the user of a computer or other product.
shortDefinitions: technical help given to user of computer

definitions: a secondary act at a pop or rock concert

examples.text: a support band

shortDefinitions: secondary act at pop or rock concert

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French beste, based on Latin bestia

definitions: an animal, especially a large or dangerous four-footed one

examples.text: a wild beast

definitions: a domestic animal, especially a bovine farm animal.
an animal as opposed to a human

examples.text: the gift of reason differentiates humanity from the beasts

definitions: an inhumanly cruel, violent, or depraved person

examples.text: he is a filthy drunken beast

definitions: an objectionable or unpleasant person or thing

examples.text: a scheming, manipulative little beast

definitions: a person's brutish or untamed characteristics

examples.text: the beast in you is rearing its ugly head

definitions: a thing or concept possessing a particular quality

examples.text: that much-maligned beast, the rave record

etymologies: mid 19th century: from Latin(see camera, camera obscura)

definitions: a device for recording visual images in the form of photographs, film, or video signals

examples.text: she faced the cameras
a photographer's camera flashed
a video camera

shortDefinitions: device for recording visual images in form of photographs

etymologies: late 17th century (denoting a council or legislative chamber in Italy or Spain): from Latin, ‘vault, arched chamber’, from Greek kamara‘object with an arched cover’

definitions: a chamber or round building

examples.text: the Radcliffe Camera
